thread.title: Experiential Learning and Presidential Management of the U.S. Federal Bureaucracy: Logic and Evidence from Agency Leadership Appointments
thread.title_full: Experiential Learning and Presidential Management of the U.S. Federal Bureaucracy: Logic and Evidence from Agency Leadership Appointments

author: George A. Krause, Anne Joseph O'Connell
title: Experiential Learning and Presidential Management of the U.S. Federal Bureaucracy: Logic and Evidence from Agency Leadership Appointments
text:
University of California, Berkeley 

Earlier versions of this paper were presented at the Eighth Annual Conference on Empirical Legal Studies (CELS), University of Pennsylvania Law School, October 25−26, 2013; the 2013 annual meeting of the Midwest Political Science Association, Chicago, Illinois, April 11−April 14; the 2011 annual meeting of the American Political Science Association, Seattle, Washington, August 31−September 3; the Harvard Political Economy and Public Law (PEPL) conference, June 2, 2011; the 2011 annual meeting of the Midwest Political Science Association, Chicago, Illinois, March 31−April 3, and the University of South Carolina. We have greatly benefitted from the comments provided by Anthony Bertelli, Ethan Bueno De Mesquita, Charles Cameron, Cary Coglianese, Steven Finkel, Sean Gailmard, Daniel Ho, Melanie Hughes, David Lewis, John Patty, Kevin Quinn, Matthew Stephenson, and participants at the University of Pennsylvania CELS and Harvard PEPL conferences, and the University of South Carolina. We also thank our team of research assistants (especially Ben Melusky) for their efforts in assisting us with compiling and coding these data, and several colleagues for their helpful suggestions during the development of this project. 
Replication Materials : The data, code, and any additional materials required to replicate all analyses in this article are available on the American Journal of Political Science Dataverse within the Harvard Dataverse Network, at: http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/E9UQ0S . Publication History Article first published online: 20 OCT 2015 SEARCH
